content.description: Start in a left facing side cling, then move straight up to a good two good horizontal jugs. Next comes a challenging traverse on horizontal crimps with bad feet. After 3-5 moves on the traverse, kick a foot out to the left for a bomber hold and reach left into a good vertical seam before bumping to jugs on the arete and finishing on easier ground up the arete.
content.location: 6 ft right of Left Arete and just right of a frequently damp low spot in the landing.

content.description: Start with a left hand pinch and right hand crimp. Move up right to a sloped crimp, and come into a left hand undercling. Go straight up from the undercling using small crimps on the face. Top out straight up. Avoid using the jugs to the far right or left.
Start matched on a low sidepull. Move up and to a sloped ledge. Continue right to the start of What's Golden Stand. Top out straight up on What's Golden Stand.
content.location: About ten feet to the right of the arete on Long Wall.

content.description: Start on the right hand sloper and left hand jug, climb straight up to top out. Good couple of easy moves to warm up. Several variations possible as well. I'm sure this has been climbed before but didn't see it on here.
content.location: Boulder all the way on the right of the long wall.

content.description: Start bunched up on a low horizontal, make a big reach up and left to a great horizontal and match. Shift right to a sharp crimp and a small left facing edge, then move up through more sharp crimps to a left facing overhanging arete at the top (fun!). Yard on the arete and top out.
content.location: Start on the wide horizontal ledge between the two large blotches of white paint on the right half of the Long Wall

content.description: Start with a left facing side pull, then move from good horizontal to good horizontal to top out between the large tree and the small tree at the top (probably will need to use the trees to top out).
content.location: On the right half of the Long Wall in the middle of the graffiti (now covered up by whitish paint)

content.description: Start with a left facing side pull, then move from great horizontal to great horizontal, then top out just left of the large tree at the top (stay mentally strong, there is no need to use the tree to top out).
content.location: 8 ft. right of the detached boulder in the middle of the wall.

content.description: Start with your left hang on the small jug on the left side of the boulder, a few feet left of the large flake that serves as the start to Egg Mantle, and your right hand just over the lip on a sloper (or anything you can find nearby). Figure out how to haul yourself up and over the lip and top out, without just traversing along the lip. It's honestly kind of a ridiculous problem, but fun footwork, and a nice change if you're tired of vertical crimps.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. Landing it sloped and covered in leaves, so pads will slide. But you're not very high off the ground, and the landing it fairly soft. I have no suggestions for protecting your dignity.
content.location: Far left side of the Easter Egg boulder. Starting hold is about five feet off the ground, a few feet to the left of the large flake.

content.description: Start on two crimps under the lip in the middle of the front face of the Easter Egg boulder, either with a high left heel hook on the jug, or some other creative foot placement. Go up to the lip, up to the sloper above that, and then top out.
content.location: Middle of the front face of the Easter Egg boulder, which is just uphill from the far (right) side of the Long Wall.

content.description: Start low on sharp crimps, move through more very sharp horizontal crimps. At the horizontal seam 10 ft up begin reaching around the arete occasionally. Near the overhung top out find a thank god horizontal on the overhung face and decipher a safe finish straight up (don't bug out to the right . . . unless you have to).
content.location: Far right end of the Long Wall

content.description: Start the same as Next To Nothing, but after going up and slightly left to the good three finger pocket, continue straight up on tiny crimps and/or whatever else you can find.
content.location: Long Wall, roughly 20 feet to the right of the left arete

content.description: Start on a good horizontal, then move up and left to a slopey horizontal or further up and right to a good hidden crimp. Make a longish move up and left to a great flake (heavily chalked), match. From here make another long reach to a slopey ledge that rises from right to left (there are good and bad spots on this ledge to grab, but all are hidden from below). Top out through the broken ledges at the top.
content.location: 8 ft. right of Witness the Wetness

content.description: Start on a horizontal flake at the bottom right side of the arete that provides good horizontals. Make a big reach to hidden, but good, holds on either side of the arete. Work up both sides of the arete to top out.
content.location: Just before and to the right of the main section of the Long Wall on the prominent overhanging arete.

content.description: Start matched on a good ledge on the bottom right of the prow (same start as Moses With A Gun),  but the pedestal if off for feet. Throw to the left, and continue up and over the prow. Avoid dabbing on the pedestal.
content.location: On your left just before you reach the Long Wall. Hard to miss.

content.description: Start the same as Moses with a Gun, then move off the starting flake to right side face of the arete. Find small sharp horizontals to establish on the face, then make a big move with your right hand to a jug that looks like a loose rock (don't worry its solid) sticking out of a horizontal seam. From the jug reach for the top and throw your left leg up onto the top out to finish.
content.location: Right side of the Moses with a Gun arete.

content.description: Start by reaching high on the left arete for jugs, start moving right. Quickly you'll encounter challenging moves on good crimps and crappy feet, before hitting a decent rest on the start holds of Witness the Wetness. After the rest decipher thin/hard moves to the start of The Crack for another rest. Stay strong as you move through the good horizontals that are the starts of the Unknown routes on the right end of the Long Wall, then finish on the right arete.
content.location: Start on the left arete of the Long Wall

content.description:
Same as "Unknown 3", but match on the second good hold after the start and double-dyno to the good jug just to the left of the base of the arete.  Top out. 

 (Not sure about the FA, as it is a variation climb, but if anyone has any suggestions or information regarding this route, please let me know!)
content.location: Same as "Unknown 3"

content.description: Start on good horizontals on either side of the arete with bad feet. Consider a right hand-foot match by heel hooking the start hold to reach higher on the arete to a good left facing hold, then match. Continue up the arete on easier ground to top out.
content.location: Left most route on the Long Wall

content.description:
Start sitting on the rock in the creek, matched on the triangular-shaped gap way at the bottom right of the slab. Throw up to the shallow cracks along the edge of the arete (without using the arete itself) until you can get over left and finish up Gateway Slab.

 The arete is off, which means you can use the shallow cracks/indentations as crimps, but not as pinches. Is this contrived? Maybe. Does it make getting over to Gateway Slab harder and more fun? It does.

 The face is quite dirty. Several of the best holds have been cleaned, but there's a risk other holds may be slippery or unstable.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. Landing is soft, but sloped, and you'll probably want something under you at the start.
content.location: Look for the flat face on your right, next to the stream, as you walk up from the Northwest Branch trail, just before you get to the Long Wall.

content.description:
Start on low crimps and follow decent crimps/pockets straight up the face. The arete and jugs on the right are off. Topout using the juggy protrusion at the top, but the tree is definitely off.

 The face is quite dirty. Several of the best holds have been cleaned, but there's a risk other holds may be slippery or unstable.
content.protection: The landing is soft, but sloped. 1 pad, or 2 if you're worried about ending up in the stream.
content.location: Look for the flat face on your right, next to the stream, as you walk up from the Northwest Branch trail, just before you get to the Long Wall.

content.description: Start on the same good jug as Witness The Wetness, but instead of traversing to better holds, climb up and slightly to the left on whatever you can find.
content.location: Start on the obvious jug about eight feet from the left arete, just before you reach the little detached boulder in the ground that's good for sitting on but makes landings a pain.

content.description: Start on the same big jug as the Egg Mantle. Find your way up to the good sloper dish, than continue right on the lip until you near the arete. Make your way upwards and to the right to finish.
content.location: Center of the Easter Egg Boulder, just up past the Long Wall.

content.description: Start on the huge jug below the lip of the overhang in the center of the Easter Egg boulder. Tall person beta is to reach straight from the start up to a positive sloper dish with your right hand. Short person beta is to use a left heel hook on the left side of the start holds, then reach for a small intermediate before bumping to the positive sloper dish. Match on the dish, find a good foot hold, then stand up. From a standing position finish the last few feet of the easy slab above the lip of the overhang.
content.location: Center of the Easter Egg overhang, right and uphill 15 yards from the right end of the Long Wall

content.description: Start on a good right crimp/flat edge and a smaller left crimp about four feet off the ground and just to the right of the triangular crack that separates the rest of the Long Wall from the left arete. Climb straight up using decent crimps and top out the same as Crap Pimp.
content.location: One of the first problems when approaching from Northwest Branch Trail. Start is just to the right of the large crack that divides the "true" left arete of Long Wall from the rest of the wall.

content.description: Start low on the left arete, same as Left Arete, at the jugs about 6ft off the ground move right a big crimp/side pull and transfer from the arete to the face. Find a small sharp block by your face that you crimp/pinch, set your feet under you and make a big reach up to decent holds about two feet below the top out. Match a ragged "V" formed by these decent holds, move your feet up and hit a sharp left rising edge with your right hand about a foot below the top out. Step up and pull over the top.
content.protection: Pad(s), spotter is nice for the hard move 12ft off the deck
content.location: Starts on the left arete.

content.description: Move up the somewhat discontinuous hand crack using horizontals next to the crack (if you want) and/or side pulls in the crack. Could make this a bit harder by restricting yourself to only crack moves.
content.location: Center of the Long Wall

content.description: Start in the overhung crack, side pull with your feet on the left wall until you can reach the right edge of the overhang. Reach for the top and finish.
content.location: Right side of the Easter Egg boulder, 15 yards uphill and right of the right end of the Long Wall

content.description: Long Wall is 40' wide by 14' to 22' high. There are a couple other boulders nearby. See robinclose.blogspot.com/201… but note the picture of the turnoff is out of date. Many contrived problems on dirty rock.
